entry.title: Ticket #29818
entry.summary:
ValueError when parsing querydata to autofill a Django admin form

After some months I sent an opinion again. I confirmed that the ticket
was not reproducible. More information was needed. Not bad.

But I sent a confusing message again. A 'POST' with URL args? It could
be interpreted as the …
entry.content:
ValueError when parsing querydata to autofill a Django admin form

After some months I sent an opinion again. I confirmed that the ticket
was not reproducible. More information was needed. Not bad.

But I sent a confusing message again. A 'POST' with URL args? It could
be interpreted as the page had been rendered and I submitted the form
with the value sent to it by URL. Trying to see the message with good eyes.

I should be sent a complete process at least. Step by step as shown in
the log messages. Or just a comment without log messages. As the other
guys did, by the way.

entry.title: JS - JQuery
entry.summary:
JS - Check

When checking JS in your project do not forget to disable
cache while DevTools(Chromium) is open. And do not close it
while you are doing the check!
entry.content:
JS - Check

When checking JS in your project do not forget to disable
cache while DevTools(Chromium) is open. And do not close it
while you are doing the check!

entry.title: Django and Celery
entry.summary:
Config Celery as a daemon

When doing the configuration to run Celery as a daemon for
your Django project, be sure that the celery-user has the
proper permissions to the log file and the working directory.
entry.content:
Config Celery as a daemon

When doing the configuration to run Celery as a daemon for
your Django project, be sure that the celery-user has the
proper permissions to the log file and the working directory.

entry.title: Django tickets
entry.summary:
First Ticket

2018-02-17

It was earlier than I expected, but it happened.

I found an "Easy picking" ticket with instructions
about what to do. It was open for months, which
means that it was not a big problem.

An "if" statement that raises a ValueError. That's
all. And some adjustments …
entry.content:
First Ticket

2018-02-17

It was earlier than I expected, but it happened.

I found an "Easy picking" ticket with instructions
about what to do. It was open for months, which
means that it was not a big problem.

An "if" statement that raises a ValueError. That's
all. And some adjustments in the form test file.

The PR was accepted, and I enjoyed each moment.

One More Ticket

One more simple bug fixed.

I was studying the ticket at the same time another guy. He set
"owner" first. But it was not a problem at the end.

He created the Pull Request and sent a solution. Then I commented
submitting a patch that was simpler and trying to explain my point
of view. He kindly accepted my suggestion, made the change, and
the PR was merged.

What a way to start a year. Two simple bugs, that's true. But they
gave me a good feeling.

obs: my comments on the ticket page were kind of messy.
PR one thing, ticket another thing. Different places.

entry.title: My packages
entry.summary:
Bye Bye Duc

The Debian package received a request for a feature. The
guy was in a rush, with bad behavior (my opinion) and the
way he wanted to fix his needs was not a good one. He knew
about a better option. An option suggested by the Policy.

I …
entry.content:
Bye Bye Duc

The Debian package received a request for a feature. The
guy was in a rush, with bad behavior (my opinion) and the
way he wanted to fix his needs was not a good one. He knew
about a better option. An option suggested by the Policy.

I asked for an opinion on debian-mentors. And there the
important thing was to choose the solution to the request.

After some useless emails someone point to the 'alternatives'
solution - the Policy choice. And I decided to stop. The
good solution was clear.

I assume my lousy humor with the issue. The issue was not a
big problem (to me), the guy preferred the 'conflicts package'
solution and he was in a hurry.

To see with kind eyes, I decided that the software is too much
important to the guy and he needed a fast solution. So I made
the package orphan and said he could assume the maintenance of
the package. Since October I do not have the software installed
anyway.

Not everybody understood I guess. But I believe nobody is feeling
bad about the issue.

entry.title: Python mixed in
entry.summary:
Mixin

I was reading the Django code, middleware, and ends up with a
Python mixin. It was good to know that I did not understand the
subject correctly. I read about it but just read is not enough
when talking about programming.

I was unable to read the code because …
entry.content:
Mixin

I was reading the Django code, middleware, and ends up with a
Python mixin. It was good to know that I did not understand the
subject correctly. I read about it but just read is not enough
when talking about programming.

I was unable to read the code because a class without inheritance
was calling 'super()'. I knew that you do not instantiate a mixin
directly. But did not know how to use it.

Henrique Bastos sent me an example that points out when the code
is mixed in the hierarchy:

class A:
.....def __init__(self):
.........print('A.__init__')

class Mixin:
....def __init__(self):
........print('Mixin.__init__')
........super().__init__()

class B(A, Mixin): pass

class C(Mixin, A): pass

.>>> A()
A.__init__

.>>> Mixin()
Mixin.__init__

.>>> B()
A.__init__

.>>> C()
Mixin.__init__
A.__init__

Mixins are used to extend a class. They provide optional customizations.
And Django project likes it.

entry.title: Security Features
entry.summary:
Deployment Checklist

There is a big difference between development and production. The
settings file needs adjust when deploying a Django project.

There are many security features in Django, and some of them should
be enabled just before the deployment. A settings file for development
and a settings file for production …
entry.content:
Deployment Checklist

There is a big difference between development and production. The
settings file needs adjust when deploying a Django project.

There are many security features in Django, and some of them should
be enabled just before the deployment. A settings file for development
and a settings file for production.

The official documentation has a checklist. And a command that can
make things easier:

django-admin check --deploy

entry.title: Get in the code
entry.summary:
What saved the week

This week I lost my workflow a little bit. But a good thread started by Bruno Santana at WTTD helped me to keep on track.

He proposed to get in the Django code using the 'messages.success(request, 'blablabla)'. An excellent exercise. And Cuducos gave helpful …
entry.content:
What saved the week

This week I lost my workflow a little bit. But a good thread started by Bruno Santana at WTTD helped me to keep on track.

He proposed to get in the Django code using the 'messages.success(request, 'blablabla)'. An excellent exercise. And Cuducos gave helpful tips.

Henrique Bastos also gave me some directions on how to deal with a Pull Request using a command line tool - git-hub.

entry.title: Fixing my dev env
entry.summary:
What was missing

The problem with the dev enviroment was: python3.5-dev Debian package was missing.

After installing the package and redo the env everything ran as expected.

summary
py3: commands succeeded
flake8: commands succeeded
docs: commands succeeded
isort: commands succeeded
congratulations :)

After that I sent my first review.
entry.content:

congratulations :)

After that I sent my first review.

entry.content:
Starting in Django project

10/30 I started reading about how to contribute to the
Django project.

I chose one ticket to make a review and today (10/31) I sent an email to django-developers because the instructions to run tests was not clear to me. The answer was to read the instructions again. :)

Let's see what 'coverage' will tell me.

entry.title: Spaces Between Words
entry.summary:
More Tough Than It Seems

The exercise today was to make a block of text like this: 

Lorem  ipsum  dolor  sit amet,  
consectetur  adipiscing  elit.  
Vestibulum    sagittis   dolor  
mauris,  at  elementum  ligula  
tempor  eget.  In quis rhoncus  
nunc,  at  aliquet orci. Fusce  
at   dolor   sit   amet  felis  
suscipit   tristique.   Nam …
entry.content:
More Tough Than It Seems

The exercise today was to make a block of text like this: 

Lorem  ipsum  dolor  sit amet,  
consectetur  adipiscing  elit.  
Vestibulum    sagittis   dolor  
mauris,  at  elementum  ligula  
tempor  eget.  In quis rhoncus  
nunc,  at  aliquet orci. Fusce  
at   dolor   sit   amet  felis  
suscipit   tristique.   Nam  a  
imperdiet   tellus.  Nulla  eu  
vestibulum    urna.    Vivamus  
tincidunt  suscipit  enim, nec  
ultrices   nisi  volutpat  ac.

See the number of spaces between words. I thought that textwrap
module, and maybe some extra module or method could do the trick.
But after some time searching in the documentation without
success I went to the web looking for an answer.

What I found wasn't what looks like on CodeWars's answers. More
than a couple of lines is necessary to achieve a block of text
like the above. The solution is at pypi.python.org - FormatBlock.
Or github - fmtblock.

The exercise is on the to-do list.

entry.title: Immutable Objects
entry.summary:
What immutable means

The value of some objects can change. Objects whose value can
change are said to be mutable; objects whose value is unchangeable
once they are created are called immutable. (The value of an
immutable container object that contains a reference to a mutable
object can change when …
entry.content:
What immutable means

The value of some objects can change. Objects whose value can
change are said to be mutable; objects whose value is unchangeable
once they are created are called immutable. (The value of an
immutable container object that contains a reference to a mutable
object can change when the latter’s value is changed; however the
container is still considered immutable, because the collection of
objects it contains cannot be changed. So, immutability is not
strictly the same as having an unchangeable value, it is more subtle.)
An object’s mutability is determined by its type; for instance,
numbers, strings and tuples are immutable, while dictionaries and
lists are mutable.

A tuple is immutable, period.

Data Model
